messages: 57676b46c102ac64708711db3e4f4ead (06:32): ok, here's a question related to the Q I asked earlier
57676b46c102ac64708711db3e4f4ead (06:32): I'm using modified redhat startup scripts
57676b46c102ac64708711db3e4f4ead (06:33): I have two scripts to start differently configured apaches: one at port 80 and another at port 9909
57676b46c102ac64708711db3e4f4ead (06:34): the problem is that once I start one, the script for the other thinks it's already started because it sees the /usr/sbin/httpd processes running
57676b46c102ac64708711db3e4f4ead (06:34): what's a good way to modify the startup scripts to notice if the http with the right -f flag is running? This is on FC5
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (06:34): two things.. obviously apache can run on two ports at the same time, and you haven't explained why you're running two instances..
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (06:35): and your scripts probably have their own pidfile mechanism, which apache (and apachectl) can deal with on its own

57676b46c102ac64708711db3e4f4ead (06:36): hm in this case the wrappers are modified from the FC5 startup scripts and don't seem to use apachectl directly. I can paste one to pastebin if that will help
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (06:38): apachectl is a script largely simillar to the chkconfig/init.d ones, accepting start and stop etc. as args.
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (06:38): and probably is easier to modify, unless you're a fedora god(ess) :)
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (06:51): 'ning daMaestro. do you know of an rpm for mod_security?
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (06:52): hehe, it's in extras, thanks imMute :D
fc86d77d6e7f42af90b3ba3a7fb99be7 (06:52): way to go imMute .. couldn't even fire up yum in time :-)
